ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: We memorize intensively human osteology.
I learned about human bones.

Learned how to identify, side and sex bones in the human body. Learned how different bones of the body connect to each other and to muscle attachments. Super cool in that you get exposure to an amazing collection of human bones that demonstrate the vast diversity in human anatomy and structure.
Learned the main contents of osteology; learned to recognize the human skeleton and its main features; learned the role of the skeleton in relation to other tissues of the human body

I learned how to identify all 206 bones as well as bone features and important muscles and nerves that originate and transmit from those features. I developed good memorizing skills that helped me do well in this class as well as how to think about bones in evolutionary and developmental aspects.

I have learned multiple specific parts of bones and get deeper understandings of the human skeletal system. I am able to identify various skeletal structures within bones and identify the directions of each bones. I got the chance to look at real human skeletons, and intrigued more of my interest towards my dream major biology.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The strengths of this class are that you learn a lot about human anatomy in a very short period of time. I believe that these are also the weaknesses of this course, as it requires vast amounts of raw memorization in short periods of time.
This course has been taught many times and it shows, Professor Sargis has honed his style of teaching and it shows. Little room for improvement.

Strengths: The fact that this was a predominantly lab-based course helped with fostering connections between students and professors, as well as giving students a sense of excitement when it comes to exploring a new system of bones. The class also allows for independent work for students who prefer to work alone. This flipped classroom aspect of the class puts the responsibility of learning in the hands of the students, and really helps with the tactile, verbal, and visual learning of the bones.

Weaknesses: None

Labs is very useful for students to get familiar with those real bone material.
The percentage of lectures could be increased

The strengths of this class include the emphasis on the lab aspect of the course, the abundantly available resources including the professor and the TF, as well as the human bone specimens we got to handle. I do not think this class had any weaknesses other than the fact that it was too short!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to anyone interested in medicine, archaeology, or anthropology, as the skills used in this class can easily be applied to those fields.

If someone is interested in anatomy, enjoys rote memorization, or needs a science credit I would recommend this course. It is not entirely a gut because one has to work, but if one puts in the requisite time, it is fairly comfortable to get a good grade.

Yes, this course is fascinating and more dynamic than other classes at Yale. It attracts a wide array of students, ranging from anthropology to history to biology majors. For those who are interested in anatomy, this is the closest thing you can get at Yale in terms of bone structure.
I would recommend this class to others. This class has a well organized curriculum and the labs are very interesting and will help us to better our studies and research in this field

Yes, definitely! The student to teacher ratio was great and you really got to ask as many questions as you had to the professor or the TF and they were more than willing to help. The hands-on aspect of the class greatly appealed to me and made the class as great as it was.

Yes because it definitely helps me to challenge myself (although I failed), but I got more understandings and knew how much I was insufficient in certain topics, and let me know myself more in a specific way through the study.

narratives.question_text: The Canvas course site allowed me to identify and access required course materials easily.
comments: Strongly Agree
Agree

Neutral

narratives.question_text: How will you use the knowledge and skills you learned in this course in your future endeavors?
comments: Depending on what I study in the future, the material learned in this course may or may not be directly applicable. However, it is nice to have a better understanding of my own body.
I think knowledge of human bones and general anatomy will inform the way that I exercise and allow me to better assess and understand any injuries I may have.
I will remember these bones when it comes to gross A&P in medical school!
As a student major in archaeology, I will apply what I have learned in this class to my fieldwork, and this class has made me more interested in physical anthropology.
I will be able to appreciate the human body even more thanks to this class as well as be able to use the skills I've learned memorizing bones and boney features in my future endeavors!

extras.title: ANTH S464 01/ARCG S464 01/E&EB S464 01 - Human Osteology
